title: Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim - Tanzanian Politician &… | Salim Ahmed Salim

quotes: He was there from December 1963 to March 1964 and this marked his second trip to China.
Dr. Salim arrived in Cairo on 20 April 1964 to report as the new representative of the People’s Republic of Zanzibar.

However, he was not able to acquire his ambassadorship – on 26 April 1964 Zanzibar and Tanganyika merged to form a union and Dr. Salim, with his credentials ready to be presented on behalf of Karume and Zanzibar, had to return to Dar es Salaam.
In June of 1964 all foreign representatives of Zanzibar and Tanganyika were called back to Dar es Salaam.
In July Dr Salim returned to Cairo and presented his credentials to President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
Dr. Salim’s tenure in Egypt was not very long – in March 1965 was transferred to India as ambassador.

organizations.name: United Front of Opposition Parties (Sauti ya Vyama Tisa)
quotes: Dr. Salim was executive secretary of the United Front of Opposition Parties (Sauti ya Vyama Tisa), which was a coalition of opposition parties with Karume as the chairman.

quotes: It was then that Dr Salim was officially appointed by President Nyerere to become the first ambassador of the Union of Zanzibar and Tanganyika, to Egypt.

quotes: Dr. Salim was executive secretary of the United Front of Opposition Parties (Sauti ya Vyama Tisa), which was a coalition of opposition parties with Karume as the chairman.

roles.title: ambassador
quotes: Karume, the leader of the revolutionary government, wanted him to serve as ambassador.

roles.title: representative of the People’s Republic of Zanzibar

roles.title: first ambassador of the Union of Zanzibar and Tanganyika
quotes: It was then that Dr Salim was officially appointed by President Nyerere to become the first ambassador of the Union of Zanzibar and Tanganyika, to Egypt.
During the Zanzibar Revolution Dr. Salim was in China assisting with translations of a pictorial publication of Chinese history into Kiswahili.
During the Zanzibar Revolution Dr. Salim was in China assisting with translations of a pictorial publication of Chinese history into Kiswahili.
Dr. Salim arrived in Cairo on 20 April 1964 to report as the new representative of the People’s Republic of Zanzibar.

However, he was not able to acquire his ambassadorship – on 26 April 1964 Zanzibar and Tanganyika merged to form a union and Dr. Salim, with his credentials ready to be presented on behalf of Karume and Zanzibar, had to return to Dar es Salaam.

In June of 1964 all foreign representatives of Zanzibar and Tanganyika were called back to Dar es Salaam. It was then that Dr Salim was officially appointed by President Nyerere to become the first ambassador of the Union of Zanzibar and Tanganyika, to Egypt.
Dr. Salim’s tenure in Egypt was not very long – in March 1965 was transferred to India as ambassador.
